title: Vindman's Twin May Be Called to Testify in Impeachment Inquiry

title: Trump Says He Is Adopting Florida as Primary Residence
summary: President abandoning New York for a crucial battleground state in 2020 election. WASHINGTON-President Trump, who spent much of his life in New York City, said Thursday that he is changing his primary residence from Manhattan to Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Video Reviews Are Hated in Soccer. That's Not the Case in Rugby.
summary: The sport has one of the most transparent video replay processes: Replays are shown on stadium screens and the conversation between the referee and the video assistant referee is broadcast. title: Defining Impeachment Down
summary: The House vote resolution and vote reveal a partisan inquiry.. Democrats on Thursday finally held a vote on their impeachment inquiry against President Trump, but the resolution and the party-line vote already foretell the likely outcome. This is a partisan impeachment driven mainly by hatred of Mr. Trump that, barring new facts, will fail in the Senate and have to be settled by the voters next November.

title: Sometimes Drug Prices Are Too Low
summary: Washington's efforts to keep medications affordable have had unintended consequences.. We're all aware of how sky-high prices can make it hard for some patients to afford the drugs they need. Yet few appreciate how patients also lose access to treatments when prices are too low.

title: 'That All Shall Be Saved' Review: Making Sense of Perdition
summary: For Christians, the idea of permanent retribution is not easily reconciled with that of a benevolent and omnipotent God.. Most Christians believe in some form of hell-and not just the modern kind in which there are lots of special places for people who commit minor outrages. How could so many millions, now and for the past 20 centuries, believe that souls who finally reject God will suffer eternal punishment? David Bentley Hart, in "That All Shall Be Saved: Heaven, Hell, and Universal Salvation," has an answer: "I am convinced that practically no one who holds firmly to the majority tradition regarding the doctrine of hell ultimately does so for any reason other than an obstinate, if largely unconscious, resolve to do so, prompted by the unshakable conviction that faith absolutely requires it."

title: Lebanon's Discontent Has Religious Roots
summary: The country was founded as a haven for Christians but has lost its purpose.. While the protests have been unifying and peaceful, at the heart of Lebanon's problems is a deep-seated identity crisis.

title: Deutsche Bank Approved Property Sale to Russian Businessman Despite Internal Objections
summary: Resume Subscription. Deutsche Bank AG officials approved the sale of a chunk of Silicon Valley real estate to a Russian businessman despite objections from its U.S. reputational risk committee, according to documents and people familiar with the matter.

title: 'The Devil Next Door' Review: A Hunted War Criminal
summary: The story of John Demjanjuk, who lived an unassuming life in America until he was accused of hiding a Nazi past.. In 1981John Demjanjuk, subject of the unnervingly vivid and rich five-part legal history "The Devil Next Door" (Monday, Netflix) was stripped of his U.S. citizenship. His had been a long battle to prevent this action-one that had begun in the late '70s when the Justice Department first charged that the retired Ford worker, a naturalized American, had concealed his past as a Nazi concentration camp guard when he entered the U.S. Having no grounds to try Demjanjuk for crimes not committed on U.S. soil, the government could only choose to revoke his citizenship.

title: 'Mount Pleasant' Review: Welcome to the Neighborhood
summary: This comedy set in suburban Manchester, England, has countless subplots and laughs to match.. It's best to forget any serious effort to follow the logic of "Mount Pleasant" (Monday, Acorn TV), a brassily incoherent comedy-drama series, set in suburban Manchester, England, that had a highly successful run in the U.K. There's no need-and, more to the point, no resolution in most of its countless subplots. There is, on the other hand, an unfailing, if wild, comic energy about the goings-on in the neighborhood and the lives of its residents that makes it irresistible. That's especially true of the young lead couple-the reasonably level-headed if slightly worn-down Lisa (Sally Lindsay) and her husband, Dan (Daniel Ryan)-and their loved ones, who include, as Lisa's spirited mother, the ever-beguiling Pauline Collins ("Upstairs, Downstairs"). Family members abound in "Mount Pleasant"-mothers, fathers, in-laws and dogs-in a way that British comedy writing excels, and these eight episodes, created by Sarah Hooper, are no exception. (The second season will be available online Monday as well.)

title: U.S. Stocks Slide Amid Uncertainty Over Trade Deal

title: Islamic State Names New Leader After Death of Baghdadi
summary: Terror group confirms the death of its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who it praised for his 'military conquests'. BEIRUT-Islamic State confirmed the death of its leader and named a successor, as the terror group attempted to move forward after a series of defeats that have eliminated its territorial control and its top-tier command.

title: 'The Irishman': Greatfellas
summary: Martin Scorsese's gangster epic, seen through the eyes of a mob hit man, is a breakthrough for the filmmaker and his stars.. After scores of celebrated films and almost half a century of richly deserved fame, Martin Scorsese did not seem poised for a breakthrough. That's what he's accomplished in "The Irishman," though, and on familiar-indeed overfamiliar-terrain. Once again he is recounting the exploits of gangsters, very bad goodfellas who whack one another without mercy and tend to come to bad ends. Once again he's working with two of his closest collaborators, Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci, plus Al Pacino, who has invested fair amounts of his own time playing persons of violent persuasion. Yet this new film, which seems shorter than its 209 minutes, feels genuinely new and deeply satisfying-for its subtlety, wit and resonance; for its serenely confident technique, meaning no truck with fancy tricks; for the sumptuous quality of the production; and for the epic scope of the story, an extraordinary tale of organized crime's grip on American life as seen through the eyes of one outwardly ordinary man.

title: 'Terminator: Dark Fate': Worse Than Death
summary: A franchise that didn't need to return does so at its peril.. Hollywood devours its own in "Terminator: Dark Fate," and another franchise bites the dust. Not just any franchise, either. The first two "Terminator" films were in a class by themselves-thrillingly original, dazzlingly conceived, and improbably stirring for their humanity. This one is in a different class-cobbled together by dunces in a last-ditch effort to wring revenue from a moribund concept. The plot makes no sense-time travel as multiverse Dada. Worse still, it renders meaningless the struggles that gave the first two films of the franchise an epic dimension. There's yet another unborn hero who will save humanity from the robots in another future that's yet to unfold, and a new set of characters notable mainly for their political correctness, plus a new Terminator, once again made of liquid-metal, whose liquidity is matched only by his vapidity.

title: Etsy Shares Post Steepest Drop in Four Years
summary: The online marketplace's shares slumped amid growth fears. Shares of Etsy Inc. slumped Thursday following the online marketplace's earnings report, posting their biggest one-day decline since August 2015. Analysts, however, suggested that the selloff was largely overdone.

title: Bill Would Force Google and Rivals to Disclose Search Algorithms
summary: Senate bill aims to give users of search engines more control over personal data. title: Time Pressure Can Squeeze the Truth
summary: A new study shows that quick responses to questions tend to be less honest than more deliberate ones.. The idea that we have two minds, an authentic inner core and a false outer layer, is as ancient as Plato and as current as the new hit movie "Joker." If our real identities are packed away, hidden even from ourselves, we seldom reveal what we really think and instead cultivate appearances-or so many psychologists believe. According to this view, the best way to get people to tell the truth is by eliciting lightning-quick responses, before they can reflect and dissemble.

summary: With its fabulous, sophisticated styling, a dependable engine and significant cargo space, Volkswagen's Arteon is a standout among the hordes of SUVs and crossovers on the road, says Dan Neil. title: Funding Wars Through the Ages
summary: U.S. antiterror efforts have cost nearly $6 trillion since the 9/11 attacks. Earlier governments from the ancient Greeks to Napoleon have had to get creative to finance their fights. The financial costs of this long war have been enormous: nearly $6 trillion to date, according to a recent report by the Watson Institute of International and Public Affairs at Brown University, which took into account not just the defense budget but other major costs, like medical and disability care, homeland security and debt.

title: Congress and the Lessons of Baghdadi's End
summary: Could Congress be trusted to keep a secret about an American raid in Syria? According to last year's Gallup poll regarding trust in various professions, most Americans wouldn't share secrets with Congress.. Your editorial "The Lessons of Baghdadi" (Oct. 28) is an interesting contrast to lessons drawn by many other commentators. You note the importance of interrogation, help from allies and forward-deployed troops that facilitated a successful raid by U.S. forces in Syria that resulted in the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. Others in news media conceded that the raid's result was good news, but faulted President Trump for his failure to give a heads-up to Congress before the raid, attributing his secrecy to political considerations related to impeachment. What President Trump actually said was that he did not inform Congress because "Adam Schiff is the biggest leaker in Washington."

title: Cuomo's Right About Limiting Gas Pipelines
summary: New York state just passed the nation's most ambitious climate bill, and all arrows are now pointed in the right direction.. Regarding your editorial "Cuomo's Carbon Contradiction" (Oct. 21): While the potential climate impacts of building more fossil-fuel infrastructure are important, New York state's ultimate decision, according to federal law, rests on the pipeline's damaging effects on water quality. New York state already denied the pipeline once on this basis, determining that the pipeline couldn't be constructed 24 miles across the mouth of New York Harbor without stirring up toxic sediments that have settled on the seafloor and causing irreparable harm to marine life.

title: Funeral Food Flavored With Kind Sympathy
summary: I, too, smiled on that very sorrowful day and fully appreciated the generosity and kindness of those lovely church ladies (and men).. Hagerty's article about funeral food ("With Deviled Eggs, Jell-O Salad, Church Volunteers Fight the Tide," Page One, Oct. 23). The funeral was truly the saddest day of my life. My brother's widow, overcome with grief, had asked several days prior whether I thought she should accept her rural Wisconsin church's luncheon offer. I thought it would be a welcome release after what I knew would be an emotional and overwrought day.

title: Hotel Scents: Love Them or Hate Them?
summary: Signature fragrances are wafting through hotels-blends of citrus and smoke, or cherries and asphalt-and not all guests are pleased. SCORES OF HOTEL companies develop their own fragrance lines, whiffable in lobbies and corridors from Boston to Bangkok. At W Hotels, a fresh, citrusy aroma trademarks the air, while the Edition Hotel's potent black tea fragrance blends citrus, chocolate, pepper and (less obviously inviting) smoke. "Kindling," as the 1 Hotels group has dubbed their fragrance, commingles eucalyptus and cardamom, with mid-notes of cedarwood. Every hotel in 1 Hotels' portfolio is redolent with the scent. Meanwhile, Hyatt's Andaz brand is tweaking the trend, customizing individual scents for each of its soon-to-be-22 locations by the end of 2019.

title: Can RoseLee Goldberg Make the World Care about Performance Art?
summary: Long relegated to culture's fringes, performance art may be the ideal art form for younger generations. How its most vocal champion wants to speak to new fans. Goldberg, who is 72 and retains a slight South African accent from her childhood in Durban, is attentive with practiced posture. Her jet-black bangs nearly cover her eyes.

"I like a really dewy, natural, sweaty look," he said, smearing Vaseline zealously over his face. Glossier founder and CEO Emily Weiss told us in an email that she doesn't mind the joke: "I love it!" The company's gleaming-skin look, initially considered niche when the brand launched in 2014, is now widely embraced. Ms. Weiss continued that the company's dewy aesthetic "is becoming more mainstream, and is aligned with a much broader shift in the beauty industry."

title: The Misguided Obsession With 'Authentic' Food

Take sauces. Knowing the "right" French sauce for each dish used to be one of the tests of a cook, but now in these more globalized times, few people would expect you to know your béarnaise from your soubise.

The attendees assembled in a hotel ballroom in Midtown Manhattan were a mix of philanthropists, scholars and attorneys.
